passages.text: Brazilian Shopping Malls (Marcelo Motta)

We are updating our estimates for Brazilian Malls (MULT, IGTI and ALOS) and establishing our Dec- 26 PT, which are on average \(15\%\) above our previous targets. We continue to flag that the sector's performance remains highly correlated to real rates; therefore our Ow is supported by JPM's bullish view on rates for 2026YE at \(10.75\%\) vs consensus at \(\sim 13.9\%\) , with cuts already starting this year. On the bottom- up front, our positive view is justified by: i) Attractive upside of \(33 - 34\%\) to our Dec- 26 PTs; ii) Spread of 310bps to long- term real rates vs historical levels of \(\sim 180\) bps (10Y); and iii) Tailwinds from non- core operations such as land plot sales, real estate development and media results. We are making small changes to our estimates, increasing FFO per share by \(6 - 9\%\) for 2026 reflecting mostly higher than expected top- line. We maintain our relative preference of MULT > IGTI > ALOS. We favor low- income homebuilders vs. malls as 2H25 should be relatively stronger as the sector counts on continuous support from the MCMV program, while Malls' results should be impacted by softer IGPM.
Megacable (Marcelo Santos, CFA) (MEGACPO MM, OW, PT Ps75.00)

We reiterate our positive view on Megacable, which is our top pick in Mexican TMT, as we see capacity utilization in the new network growing and capex declining, paving the way for improved cash flow generation. We update our estimates and price target to account for: (1) lower capex and higher number of homes passed; (2) a more moderate view on growth and specifically margin expansion into 2026, given the tough competitive environment; (3) lower WACC, at \(11.7\%\) vs \(12.0\%\) previously; and (4) the Tollover effect of the target. All in all, we are establishing a Ps 75 target for Dec- 26, which compares to our previous Dec- 25 PT of Ps 63, suggesting \(37\%\) potential upside.
Brazilian Bartks (Yuri R Fernandes)

Brazil's Central Bank published credit data for July with negative data for agro and Banco do Brasil - 90- days NPL was up \(+75\) bps M- o- M and early 15- 90 days NPL worsened \(\sim 40\) bps M- o- M (driven by earmarked rates). As for the system, we have a mixed first take: (1) loan growth remained stable at \(10.7\%\) Y- o- Y, although we note some marginal acceleration from foreign players (e.g. Santander) at \(0.5\%\) M- o- M; (2) NPLs rose 20bps M- o- M to \(3.8\%\) (while accounting changes may still distort the numbers we believe July is a more normalized data) - worsening was led by public banks (+30bps), while private and foreign banks were less pronounced (+10bps); (3) spreads were down 20bps M- o- M or 10bps for non- directed loans.
LatAm Food & Beverages (Lucas Ferreira)

Today we hosted the Food & Beverages day of our \(19^{\text{th}}\) Brazil Consumer and Healthcare Check- up Conference, in partnership with our colleagues Joseph Giordano & team. Companies hosted include JBS, KOF, M Dias and Minerva. Please find the highlights below and feel free to reach out to us if you have any questions.
